solution: First, multiply both sides by the denominator to obtain $\sqrt[3]{2x-4} = 2\sqrt[3]{x+4}$. Cubing both sides, $$2x-4 = 8 \cdot (x+4) = 8x + 32.$$Thus, $6x = -36 \Longrightarrow x = \boxed{-6}$.
model_solution:
\frac{\sqrt[3]{2x-4}}{\sqrt[3]{x+4}} = 2 \\ \sqrt[3]{2x-4}=2\sqrt[3]{x+4}
$(\sqrt[3]{2x-4})^3=(2\sqrt[3]{x+4})^3$
$8x-64=8x+32$
$-64=32$
This step does not follow from the previous steps and appears to be an error. The correct step is:

$2(2x-4)=2^3(x+4)$
$2(2x-4)=2^3(x+4)$
$2(2x-4)=2^3(x+4)$
